author: First Alert Meteorologist Steve Rudin
title: The Commanders are on a winning streak, the best s
text:
The Commanders are on a winning streak, the best since 2006 and their next destination is the Motor City. If you have tickets for the big game Saturday evening, it would be worthwhile to set aside some time to explore a few unique Detroit attractions and restaurants.
The Henry Ford Museum of American Innovation
20900 Oakwood Blvd, Dearborn, MI 48124
thehenryford.org
This is Detroit’s answer to the Smithsonian. Cars, planes, trains, this place has it all. Besides the big game, this may be the highlight of your trip.
Active exhibits include: With Liberty and Justice for All, Driving America and Presidential Vehicles. This exhibit showcases various vehicles, including the horse-drawn carriage utilized by Theodore Roosevelt and the presidential parade cars that transported Franklin D. Roosevelt, Harry Truman, Dwight D. Eisenhower, Gerald Ford, Jimmy Carter, Ronald Reagan, and George H. W. Bush. Among these, the standout vehicle is the 1961 Lincoln Continental Presidential Limousine, which tragically carried John F. Kennedy during his assassination on November 22, 1963. This vehicle underwent reconstruction and went on to be frequently used by Lyndon B. Johnson and Richard Nixon. Motown Museum
2648 W Grand Blvd, Detroit, MI 48208
motownmuseum.org
Detroit Institute of Arts
5200 Woodward Ave, Detroit, MI 48202
dia.org
The Detroit Institute of Arts is renowned for its exceptional art collection, which is widely regarded as one of the best in the United States. With over 65,000 works, the museum exhibits a diverse range of art, from mummies and modern art to African masks and Monets.
Be sure to visit the Center for African American Art, within the DIA, where you can explore a remarkable gallery featuring 400 pieces created by African American artists in various media. Lafayette Coney Island
118 W Lafayette Blvd, Detroit, MI 48226
American Coney Island
114 W Lafayette Blvd, Detroit, MI 48226
americanconeyisland,com
This is very Detroit, and visitors may be wary to try. Think Ben’s Chili Bowl, kinda. Both Lafayette and American are renowned for their hot dogs, served on steamed buns and topped with chili, onions, and mustard. Located next to each other, locals have a favorite - although it is pretty hard to tell the difference.
The Coney dog has its origins rooted in Greek immigrants who relocated from Coney Island, New York to Detroit during the early 20th century. These immigrants bestowed a Greek touch upon the American hot dog by incorporating a chili sauce infused with traditional Greek spices. Leo’s Coney Island is a favorite if you are staying in the suburbs.
Buddy’s Pizza
1565 Broadway Street, Detroit, MI 48226
buddyspizza.com
Established in 1946, Buddy’s Pizza is renowned for pioneering the Detroit-style square pie. Reminiscent of a Sicilian tomato pizza, this square delicacy features a spongy crust with with crusty, caramelized cheese edges. Toppings, including the sauce go over the cheese.
Stage Deli
6873 Orchard Lake Rd, West Bloomfield Township, MI 48322
stagedeli.com
If you find yourself in the suburbs and craving the authentic flavors of a traditional New York City-style Jewish deli, look no further than the Stage Deli in West Bloomfield. Their offerings, from piled-high corned beef on freshly baked seedless rye, promise an unforgettable experience. Don’t miss out on their latkes and matzo ball soup. The Stage Deli has been serving customers since 1962 and remains a beloved family-owned restaurant. Order ahead for carry-out.
Mike’s Famous Ham Place
3700 Michigan Ave, Detroit, MI 48216
If you are a fan of Virginia ham, then this could be the ideal spot for you to satisfy your cravings while in Detroit. The original lunch counter has proudly stood here since the 1950s, and remarkably, not much has altered throughout the years. The star of the show - ham: whether paired with eggs and toast, on a poppy-seed bun, or covered with split-pea soup. Last year, Mike’s Famous Ham landed on The New York Times’ list of “26 of the Best Dishes We Ate Across the U.S.”
Mexicantown Bakery
4300 Vernor Hwy, Detroit, MI 48209
mexicantownbakery.com
Looking for a sweet treat, be sure to check out Detroit's Mexicantown has been around since the 1920s. A favorite is the Mexicantown Bakery.

author: Mohamed Elkorri
title: ​Exportations de produits phosphatiers : Le Maroc assure 48.000 tonnes pour l'Argentine juste en décembre 2024
text:
Le Maroc vient de boucler une transaction d'exportation d'engrais vers l'Argentine, indiquent des sources au sein de l'autorité portuaire à San Lorenzo en Argentine à L'Opinion.
Il s'agit d'une exportation de 15.000 tonnes de roches phosphatées dont la destination est San Lorenzo avec une arrivée prévue le 1er février 2025.
Cette cargaison s'ajoute à celles déjà concrétisées le 6 décembre comme l'avait indiqué
Pour rappel, les cours de roches phosphatées affichent une stabilité depuis le mois de janvier 2024, en se situant à 152,50 dollars/ tonne métrique.
Cette cargaison sera chargée sur le vraquier LAKE GRASSMERE. C'est un vraquier battant pavillon panaméen, sa longueur hors est de 182,93 mètres et sa largeur est de 31 mètres.
Cependant, les deux autres expéditions seront chargées sur le vraquier "BUNUN TREASURE", un vraquier battant du Libéria.
Pour les importations du Maroc depuis ce pays sud-américain pour le mois de décembre, L'Opinion avait précisé la semaine dernière que le Maroc attend deux cargaisons du tourteau de soja et de granulés de coque de soja de l'Argentine d'un total de 24.000 tonnes de la première et 6000 tonnes de la seconde,
Le chargement de cette cargaison s'effectuera le 27 décembre du port de San Lorenzo.
A titre d'information, la tendance baissière des cours des tourteaux de soja qui s’est installée depuis le début d'octobre semble laisser place à la stabilité. Le prix de la tonne de soja s’affiche désormais à 373 dollars/ tonne.
Quant aux granulés de la coque de soja, ils se situent à 292,1 dollars/tonne.
Le navire qui importera cette cargaison au Maroc dudit port argentin est ZBB SERENITY. Il s'agit d'un vraquier battant sous le pavillon de Malte, sa longueur totale est de 189,99 mètres et sa largeur est de 28,5 mètres.
Il s'agit d'une exportation de 15.000 tonnes de roches phosphatées dont la destination est San Lorenzo avec une arrivée prévue le 1er février 2025.
Cette cargaison s'ajoute à celles déjà concrétisées le 6 décembre comme l'avait indiqué

Cependant, les deux autres expéditions seront chargées sur le vraquier "BUNUN TREASURE", un vraquier battant du Libéria.
Pour les importations du Maroc depuis ce pays sud-américain pour le mois de décembre, L'Opinion avait précisé la semaine dernière que le Maroc attend deux cargaisons du tourteau de soja et de granulés de coque de soja de l'Argentine d'un total de 24.000 tonnes de la première et 6000 tonnes de la seconde,
selon la même source.
Le chargement de cette cargaison s'effectuera le 27 décembre du port de San Lorenzo.
A titre d'information, la tendance baissière des cours des tourteaux de soja qui s’est installée depuis le début d'octobre semble laisser place à la stabilité. Le prix de la tonne de soja s’affiche désormais à 373 dollars/ tonne.
Quant aux granulés de la coque de soja, ils se situent à 292,1 dollars/tonne.

title: Ground News - Rio: higher risks of flooding are in Metropolis and downtown.
text:

author: RUSS VERNON-JONES
title: Columnist Russ Vernon-Jones: American Climate Corps — The CCC reborn
text:
Columnist Russ Vernon-Jones: American Climate Corps — The CCC reborn
|Published: 07-18-2024 4:08 PM|
Last month, the first 9,000 members of the new American Climate Corps were
sworn in and started work. This federal program is designed to train young people and engage them in new government-funded jobs in the clean energy, conservation, and climate resilience sectors. It’s modeled on the Civilian Conservation Corps (CCC) that FDR created as part of the New Deal in the 1930s. I’ve been a supporter of this new Corps since it was first proposed back in 2020.
When I heard that one of my longtime favorite authors, the widely heralded Barbara Kingsolver, had written the pledge that the new Corps members would recite in their swearing-in ceremony, I was intrigued. The text of the pledge touched and charmed me. I wanted to share this pledge with Gazette readers and that led to this column.
In my early 20s I visited Great Smokey Mountains National Park as both a hiker and as a tourist. I slept in cabins, walked over bridges, and enjoyed spectacular views from overlooks, all of which had small plaques indicating they had been built in the 1930s by the Civilian Conservation Corps. Eventually, I learned that the CCC had been one of FDR’s programs to put people into meaningful jobs at government expense in the midst of the economic crisis of the Great Depression. I was impressed that a program created to meet the unemployment crisis decades earlier was still providing the public with so many benefits.
This week I researched just a little of the history of the CCC and learned that they planted a vast number of trees, built thousands of dams, bridges, buildings, water supply systems, and built much of the infrastructure of the U.S. National Park System all over the U.S.
Now we are in a severe climate crisis. Having the government get young people engaged in vital work to respond to the crisis makes a lot of sense to me. The idea was first proposed and pushed during the 2020 presidential campaign by the Sunrise Movement, the youth climate movement that played a key role in building support for the Green New Deal. Our own Massachusetts Senator Ed Markey, along with Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, working with
Sunrise, introduced legislation that would fund and create the Climate Corps.
Hundreds of Sunrise young people visited their congressional offices, talked to everyone they knew, and put on over 100 rallies and actions in support of a civilian Climate Corps. They led three long marches across the country, blockaded the White House, campaigned for the Corps relentlessly, and built widespread support for the idea. Their skillful, persistent, sustained advocacy and organizing finally made a difference.
In September of 2023 President Joe Biden took
[executive action]() to initiate the American Climate Corps — “a workforce training and service initiative that will ensure more young people have access to the skills-based training necessary for good-paying careers in the clean energy and climate resilience economy.” He committed to putting more than 20,000 to work “conserving and restoring our lands and waters, bolstering community resilience, deploying clean energy, implementing energy efficient technologies, and advancing environmental justice.”
These are a variety of paid positions ranging from a few months to over a year. They are funded through the Inflation Reduction Act and the federal budget. Most are designed to bolster local community efforts — installing clean energy, restoring habitats, weatherizing buildings, instituting climate-resilient farming practices, and more. All involve training and will prepare participants to go on to more permanent jobs in both the private and public sectors that will make a difference in the climate crisis.
Article continues after...
Yesterday's Most Read Articles
[Elements Massage studio in Hadley abruptly closes after state order](/Hadley-massage-business-closed-56033365) [Amherst Town Council rejects candidate over tilt toward abutters](/Amherst-Town-Council-nixes-recommended-appointment-to-Planning-Board-over-candidate-s-views-56046392) [Area property deed transfers, July 18](/Area-property-deed-transfers-July-18-56040154) [Around the Hamptons: ‘Wild cows’ find way back to Easthampton home; local internet testing; Blueberry Supper in Westhampton](/Around-the-Hamptons-56028404) [Prominent immigration law firm in Northampton to close, affecting 30-plus employees](/CBK-immigration-to-close-at-the-end-of-July-56054087) [Music in the sky: Summit House Sunset Concert Series returns to its 173-year-old home](/summit-house-concert-series-july-13-55988054)
Barbara Kingsolver is excited about the American Climate Corps. She
described the pledge she wrote this way: “In less than 100 words, I tried to bring in the most important parts of this initiative — that it’s about respecting and bringing justice to communities, it’s about respecting and honoring the environment and our connection with it, and it’s about taking a part in history.”
Here is the pledge that the first 9,000 members of the American Climate Corps committed to last month. How much of this can we all commit to?
I pledge to bring my skills, respect, and compassion to work every day, supporting environmental justice in all our communities.
I will honor nature’s beauty and abundance, on which we all depend, and commit to its protection from the climate crisis.
I will build a more resilient future, where every person can thrive.
I will take my place in history, working with shared purpose in the American Climate Corps on behalf of our nation and planet, its people, and all its species, for the better future we hold within our sight.
Russ Vernon-Jones of Amherst is a member of the Steering Committee of Climate Action Now (CAN). The views expressed here are his own. His column appears in the Gazette on the third Friday of each month. He blogs regularly on climate justice at http://www.russvernonjones.org and can be reached there.
